content.text:
> Wait, wait, wait, start for what? Curtailing dotfiles period? Individual customization?

I want to clarify that this blog post isn't against dotfiles in general, it's just encouraging developers to conform to the [XDG Base Directory Specification](https://specifications.freedesktop.org/basedir-spec/latest/) when doing so. It's true that dotfiles are a unix tradition, but so is the pattern of separating concerns. I'm super appreciative of all of the work that's gone into freedesktop.org (previously X Desktop Group) and [all of its specifications](https://www.freedesktop.org/wiki/Specifications/) and I think that consistency is empowering to everyone using the system.

> Furthermore their argument for using XDG doesn't actually change anything about their original argument of dot files being created without their wanting them or the fact that many are recreated after deleting them.

I agree here, my main critique of this article is that the author is using the grumpy "I don't like the status quo" rather than the optimistic "it would be cool if we did this thing!" and I don't think the grumpiness makes a convincing case. I think that consistency, customization, and interoperability are all positive *plus* if [the rest of my OS](https://wiki.debian.org/XDGBaseDirectorySpecification) is aiming to follow this convention I'm happy to do the same (especially since it's been [requested](https://github.com/ssbc/ssb-server/issues/435)).
